factors: Being So Restless That It’s Hard to Sit Still
Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
Worrying Too Much About Different Things

items.text: Little things that never used to bother me now make me snap at people.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Directly describes increased irritability and lowered threshold for annoyance, core to this factor.

items.text: I find myself getting irritated over minor inconveniences throughout the day.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Describes a pattern of disproportionate irritation to small triggers.

items.text: My patience has worn thin and I lose my temper much more easily than I used to.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Captures the erosion of patience and increased temper that characterizes anxiety-related irritability.

items.text: People around me have noticed that I seem more short-tempered lately.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Third-person observation of increased irritability, a hallmark of this factor.

items.text: I get annoyed when someone interrupts me, even if it's for something important.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Describes disproportionate annoyance response to normal social interactions.

items.text: Even the sound of someone chewing or tapping their pen can set me off.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Heightened sensory irritability is a common manifestation of anxiety-driven annoyance.

items.text: I feel like I'm constantly on a short fuse and could blow up at any moment.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Vivid first-person description of chronic irritability and low frustration tolerance.

items.text: I've been snapping at my family members for no good reason.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Behavioral description of irritability manifesting in close relationships.

items.text: Traffic, long lines, and slow service make me disproportionately angry.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Describes exaggerated irritation responses to everyday frustrations.

items.text: I feel irritable most of the day, even when nothing specific has gone wrong.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Captures the pervasive, free-floating nature of anxiety-related irritability.

items.text: Small mistakes by coworkers or friends make me unreasonably frustrated.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Describes disproportionate frustration in response to others' minor errors.

items.text: I've noticed I'm more easily provoked and quicker to argue than usual.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Self-awareness of increased argumentativeness tied to irritability.

items.text: When I'm feeling tense, the smallest thing can make me lash out.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Connects irritability to underlying tension, which could also relate to trouble relaxing or feeling on edge.

items.text: I get agitated and cranky when things don't go according to plan.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Agitation could overlap with restlessness, but the emphasis on crankiness anchors it to irritability.

items.text: I feel so wound up inside that I can't help but snap at people and I can't sit still.
items.expected_factor: Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable
items.rationale: Combines irritability with restlessness, making it a boundary item between these two factors.
items.boundary_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still

items.text: I can't seem to sit still — I'm always fidgeting, tapping my foot, or shifting in my seat.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Directly describes psychomotor restlessness with specific behavioral examples.

items.text: During meetings or meals, I feel a constant urge to get up and move around.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Describes the compulsion to move in situations requiring stillness.

items.text: My body feels like it's buzzing with nervous energy that I can't discharge.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Captures the somatic experience of restless energy characteristic of this factor.

items.text: People have commented that I seem jittery and unable to stay in one place.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Third-person observation of observable restless behavior.

items.text: I pace around the house because sitting down feels almost impossible.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Describes pacing as a behavioral manifestation of inability to sit still.

items.text: Even when I'm supposed to be resting, my legs keep bouncing and my hands keep moving.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Specific psychomotor symptoms occurring even during intended rest periods.

items.text: I feel physically restless, like I need to keep moving or I'll crawl out of my skin.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Vivid somatic description of the restlessness experience with urgency.

items.text: Sitting through a movie or a long dinner has become nearly unbearable for me.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Describes functional impairment in everyday activities due to restlessness.

items.text: I find myself getting up repeatedly from my desk because I just can't stay seated.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Workplace-specific behavioral description of restlessness.

items.text: There's a restless energy in my body that makes it hard to be still for even a few minutes.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Describes the pervasive physical restlessness with a time-based qualifier.

items.text: I constantly shift positions, cross and uncross my legs, and can't get comfortable.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Detailed behavioral description of motor restlessness.

items.text: My partner says I toss and turn all night because I can't settle my body down.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Third-person report of restlessness extending into sleep behavior.

items.text: I feel keyed up and physically agitated, like my body won't let me be calm.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: The phrase 'keyed up' and 'won't let me be calm' could overlap with trouble relaxing, but the physical agitation anchors it here.

items.text: I have so much nervous energy that I can't focus on anything because I keep needing to move.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: Combines restlessness with concentration difficulty; the movement emphasis keeps it in this factor.

items.text: I can't sit still and I can't seem to unwind no matter what I try.
items.expected_factor: Being So Restless That It's Hard to Sit Still
items.rationale: The inability to unwind overlaps significantly with Trouble Relaxing, while the inability to sit still is core to this factor.

items.text: I have a constant sense of dread, as though something terrible is about to happen.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Directly captures the anticipatory dread and catastrophic expectation central to this factor.

items.text: I wake up each morning with a feeling that something bad is going to happen today.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Describes morning-onset anticipatory fear without a specific trigger.

items.text: I feel a deep sense of fear that I can't explain, like disaster is just around the corner.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Captures the irrational, pervasive fear of impending catastrophe.

items.text: When my phone rings unexpectedly, my first thought is that someone has died or been hurt.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Describes catastrophic interpretation of neutral stimuli, a hallmark of this factor.

items.text: I feel like I'm bracing for impact all the time, waiting for the next awful thing.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Vivid metaphor capturing the chronic anticipatory fear state.

items.text: There's a pit in my stomach that tells me something horrible is going to happen.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Somatic experience of dread tied to catastrophic expectation.

items.text: I can't shake the feeling that something awful is looming over me.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Describes persistent, unshakeable sense of impending doom.

items.text: Even when things are going well, I feel afraid that everything could fall apart at any moment.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Fear persists despite positive circumstances, indicating the irrational nature of the dread.

items.text: I sometimes feel paralyzed by the fear that something catastrophic will happen to my loved ones.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Catastrophic fear focused on loved ones with functional impairment (paralysis).

items.text: I have an overwhelming sense that the worst-case scenario is always the most likely one.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Describes catastrophic probability bias, a cognitive feature of this factor.

items.text: My heart races when I think about the future because I'm convinced something bad will happen.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Combines physiological arousal with future-oriented catastrophic fear.

items.text: I feel a sense of impending doom that follows me throughout the day.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: Classic description of pervasive impending doom, directly mapping to this factor.

items.text: I keep imagining terrible things happening and I can't stop the fearful thoughts.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: The inability to stop the thoughts introduces overlap with Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying, but the fear content anchors it here.

items.text: I'm afraid something awful will happen and I find myself worrying about it constantly.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: The constant worrying element introduces some overlap with uncontrollable worry, but the fear of awful outcomes is primary.

items.text: I lie awake at night terrified about what might go wrong, running through every possible disaster.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen
items.rationale: The running through disasters element overlaps with Worrying Too Much About Different Things, while the terror anchors it to this factor.
items.boundary_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things

items.text: I feel nervous and on edge from the moment I wake up until I go to sleep.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Directly describes pervasive nervousness throughout the day, core to this factor.

items.text: There's a constant knot of anxiety in my chest that never seems to go away.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Somatic manifestation of chronic anxiety with emphasis on persistence.

items.text: I feel like I'm always waiting for the other shoe to drop — just constantly tense.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Captures the chronic tension and hypervigilance of being on edge.

items.text: My nerves feel frayed and I startle easily at unexpected sounds.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Describes heightened startle response and frayed nerves, classic anxiety symptoms.

items.text: I have a general sense of unease that I carry with me everywhere I go.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Describes pervasive, non-specific anxiety that is characteristic of this factor.

items.text: I feel anxious even in situations where there's nothing to be anxious about.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Highlights the irrational, context-independent nature of generalized anxiety.

items.text: My hands tremble and my stomach churns because I feel so nervous all the time.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Physical symptoms directly tied to chronic nervousness.

items.text: I feel like I'm walking on eggshells, always braced for something to go wrong.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Metaphor capturing the hypervigilant, on-edge quality of generalized anxiety.

items.text: Even ordinary conversations make me feel nervous and uneasy.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Anxiety intruding into mundane daily interactions indicates pervasive nervousness.

items.text: I feel a low-level hum of anxiety running through me at all times.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Describes the chronic, baseline anxiety state central to this factor.

items.text: My body is tense and my mind is racing — I just feel on edge constantly.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Combines physical tension and cognitive racing, both hallmarks of feeling on edge.

items.text: I feel jittery and unsettled, as if something is wrong but I can't pinpoint what.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: Describes free-floating anxiety without identifiable cause.

items.text: I feel so anxious that it's hard for me to let go and just relax.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: The difficulty relaxing introduces overlap with Trouble Relaxing, but the primary experience described is anxiety.

items.text: I'm so on edge that every little noise or unexpected event makes my heart pound.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: The startle and reactivity could overlap with irritability, but the on-edge framing keeps it in this factor.

items.text: I feel nervous and keyed up, and I can't stop my mind from jumping to worst-case scenarios.
items.expected_factor: Feeling Nervous, Anxious, or On Edge
items.rationale: The worst-case scenario thinking overlaps with Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen, while the nervousness is core to this factor.
items.boundary_factor: Feeling Afraid as if Something Awful Might Happen

items.text: Once I start worrying, I can't turn it off no matter how hard I try.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Directly describes the inability to stop worry once initiated, the core of this factor.

items.text: I tell myself to stop worrying but my mind just won't listen.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Captures the failed attempts at cognitive control over worry.

items.text: My worrying feels completely out of my control, like a runaway train.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Vivid metaphor for the uncontrollable nature of worry.

items.text: I've tried deep breathing, distraction, and everything else, but I still can't stop the worrying.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Describes failed coping strategies, emphasizing the intractable nature of the worry.

items.text: Even when I know my worries are irrational, I can't make them stop.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Insight into irrationality combined with inability to control worry is a hallmark of this factor.

items.text: My mind gets stuck in a loop of worry and I can't break free from it.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Describes the repetitive, stuck quality of uncontrollable worry.

items.text: I feel helpless against my own worrying — it has a life of its own.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Captures the sense of helplessness and autonomy of the worry process.

items.text: People tell me to just stop worrying, but if I could, I would have done it already.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Reflects frustration with others' misunderstanding of the uncontrollable nature of worry.

items.text: I spend hours trying to talk myself out of worrying, but it never works.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Describes time spent in failed attempts to control worry.

items.text: My worries spiral out of control and I can't rein them back in.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Describes escalation and loss of control over the worry process.

items.text: I wish I could flip a switch and turn off my worrying, but it's impossible.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Expresses desire for control contrasted with perceived impossibility.

items.text: The worrying takes over my mind and I lose the ability to think about anything else.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: Describes cognitive domination by uncontrollable worry.

items.text: I can't control my worrying and it keeps me up most nights.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: The sleep disruption could relate to trouble relaxing, but the emphasis on uncontrollable worry anchors it here.

items.text: My worrying is relentless — it jumps from one topic to the next and I can't stop it.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: The topic-jumping element introduces some overlap with Worrying Too Much About Different Things, but the inability to stop is primary.

items.text: I can't stop worrying about all the different things that could go wrong in my life.
items.expected_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
items.rationale: The 'different things' element maps to Worrying Too Much About Different Things, while the 'can't stop' maps to this factor.
items.boundary_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things

items.text: No matter what I do, I can't seem to unwind or let go of the tension in my body.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Directly describes the inability to relax physically despite effort.

items.text: Even on vacation, I find it impossible to truly relax and enjoy myself.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Inability to relax persists even in optimal relaxation conditions.

items.text: I try to do calming activities like reading or taking a bath, but I still feel wound up.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Describes failed relaxation attempts despite engaging in calming activities.

items.text: My muscles are always tight and I carry tension in my shoulders and jaw.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Chronic muscle tension is a somatic hallmark of trouble relaxing.

items.text: I don't remember the last time I felt truly relaxed and at ease.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Captures the chronic absence of relaxation over an extended period.

items.text: When I sit down to rest, my mind and body refuse to cooperate — I just can't relax.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Describes both mental and physical inability to relax during intended rest.

items.text: Weekends and days off don't feel restorative because I can never fully unwind.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Inability to relax impairs recovery during leisure time.

items.text: I feel like there's a coiled spring inside me that never releases.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Vivid metaphor for chronic internal tension and inability to relax.

items.text: People tell me I need to relax, but I genuinely don't know how to anymore.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Describes loss of the ability to relax, with social feedback confirming the problem.

items.text: I can't enjoy leisure activities because I'm unable to let go of the tension I'm carrying.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Functional impairment in leisure due to persistent tension.

items.text: Even after exercising, which is supposed to help, I still feel tense and unable to relax.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Exercise as a failed relaxation strategy highlights the severity of the relaxation difficulty.

items.text: My body feels like it's always in 'go mode' and I can't switch it off.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: Describes chronic physiological activation and inability to downregulate.

items.text: I lie in bed at night unable to relax because my mind keeps churning with thoughts.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: The churning thoughts could overlap with uncontrollable worry, but the primary complaint is inability to relax.

items.text: I feel tense and uptight all day, and it makes it hard to enjoy anything.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: The all-day tension could overlap with feeling on edge, but the emphasis on inability to enjoy maps to trouble relaxing.

items.text: I'm so tense that I can't relax, and it's making me increasingly irritable with everyone.
items.expected_factor: Trouble Relaxing
items.rationale: The irritability component overlaps with Becoming Easily Annoyed or Irritable, while the tension and inability to relax are core to this factor.

items.text: I worry about everything — my health, my finances, my relationships, my job, all of it.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Directly describes worry spanning multiple life domains, the hallmark of this factor.

items.text: My mind jumps from one worry to the next — as soon as I resolve one concern, another takes its place.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Describes the shifting, multi-topic nature of excessive worry.

items.text: I find things to worry about that most people wouldn't even think twice about.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Captures the excessive and disproportionate scope of worry across topics.

items.text: On any given day, I'm worrying about at least five or six completely different things.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Quantifies the breadth of worry topics, directly mapping to this factor.

items.text: I worry about big things and small things equally — nothing is too trivial to worry about.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Describes the indiscriminate nature of excessive worry across importance levels.

items.text: My worries cover everything from whether I locked the door to whether the economy will collapse.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Illustrates the vast range of worry topics from mundane to global.

items.text: I spend most of my day worrying about one thing after another.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Describes the time-consuming, sequential nature of multi-topic worry.

items.text: Friends say I'm a chronic worrier because I always find something new to be anxious about.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Third-person observation of the pattern of finding new worry topics.

items.text: I worry about my children, my parents, my work deadlines, and my health all at the same time.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Lists simultaneous worries across multiple domains.

items.text: It feels like there's always something to worry about — the list never ends.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Describes the inexhaustible nature of worry topics.

items.text: I worry excessively about things that are unlikely to happen and things that are completely out of my control.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Captures the excessive and broad nature of worry including low-probability and uncontrollable events.

items.text: My worrying isn't focused on one thing — it's scattered across every area of my life.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: Explicitly describes the diffuse, multi-domain quality of the worry.

items.text: I worry so much about so many things that it's exhausting just to get through the day.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: The exhaustion element could relate to trouble relaxing, but the emphasis on volume and variety of worries anchors it here.

items.text: I catch myself worrying about things that haven't happened yet and probably never will, across every part of my life.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: The anticipatory nature could overlap with feeling afraid something awful might happen, but the breadth of topics is primary.

items.text: I worry about so many different things that once I start, I can't seem to stop.
items.expected_factor: Worrying Too Much About Different Things
items.rationale: The inability to stop overlaps with Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying, while the many different things maps to this factor.
items.boundary_factor: Not Being Able to Stop or Control Worrying
